section.title: net-define
section.para: Adds a new persistent virtual network to libvirt, without starting it, using settings from an XML file.
Unless you enable automatic starting of it, by the libvirt daemon when it starts, you will need to manually start this virtual network as needed, using .
To enable automatic starting of this virtual network, use the virsh command.

entry.para: The full path (and file name) to an XML file containing the network settings required.

example.para: Creates a new, persistent, virtual network using the settings from the XML file /root/examplenetwork.xml.

listitem.para: Starting with an XML file we've already created, using the required XML format:
We start virsh interactively, then create the transient virtual network:
listitem.screen:
# virsh Welcome to virsh, the virtualization interactive terminal.
Type: 'help' for help with commands 'quit' to quit
virsh # net-list Name State Autostart ----------------------------------------- default active yes
virsh # net-define /root/examplenetwork.xml Network examplenetwork defined from /root/examplenetwork.xml
virsh # net-list --all Name State Autostart ----------------------------------------- default active yes examplenetwork inactive no
listitem.para: Newly defined virtual networks aren't automatically started, so we manually start it now:
listitem.screen: virsh # net-start examplenetwork Network examplenetwork started
virsh # net-list Name State Autostart ----------------------------------------- default active yes examplenetwork active no
listitem.para: We check the details of the started network from virsh. This shows us the generated UUID, and anything else that may be in effect (ie Spanning Tree Protocol).
listitem.screen: virsh # net-dumpxml examplenetwork <network> <name>examplenetwork</name> <uuid>97ce3914-231e-4026-0a78-822e1e2e7226</uuid> <forward mode='route'/> <bridge name='virbr100' stp='on' delay='0' /> <ip address='10.10.120.1' netmask='255.255.255.0'> </ip> </network>
listitem.para: If the virtualisation server is running Linux, we can check how it appears to the host OS:
listitem.screen: # ifconfig virbr100 virbr100 Link encap:Ethernet HWaddr A6:45:97:AE:8E:08 inet addr:10.10.120.1 Bcast:10.10.120.255 Mask:255.255.255.0 UP BROADCAST RUNNING MULTICAST MTU:1500 Metric:1 RX packets:0 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0 TX packets:11 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0 collisions:0 txqueuelen:0 RX bytes:0 (0.0 b) TX bytes:2653 (2.5 KiB)
